curam.util.client.domain.convert
Class SvrMoneyConverter

java.lang.Object
  curam.util.common.plugin.AbstractPlugIn
      curam.util.common.domain.AbstractDomainPlugIn
          curam.util.client.domain.AbstractClientDomainPlugIn
              curam.util.client.domain.convert.AbstractConverter
                  curam.util.client.domain.convert.SvrMoneyConverter
All Implemented Interfaces:
curam.util.client.domain.convert.ClientDomainConverter, DomainConverter, DomainPlugIn, PlugIn
public class SvrMoneyConverter
extends AbstractConverter

A converter for the SVR_MONEY domain. Money values are double-precision floating-point values but are limited in magnitude to prevent rounding errors. The maximum magnitude is 10,000,000,000,000.00 (1.0e13 or ten trillion). Values representing fractions of a cent will be rounded to the nearest whole cent (including zero). When parsing values, locale-specific grouping separators will be accepted, though they are optional. The decimal point character is locale-specific. The generic format must use a period character as the decimal point and may optionally use commas as a thousands separator.

Field Detail

MAX_MONEY_MAGNITUDE

public static final double MAX_MONEY_MAGNITUDE
The maximum permitted magnitude of a money value. This is determined by the number of significant digits that can be represented by a denormalized IEEE 754 double-precision floating-point number as represented by the Java primitive "double" type. The denormalized representation guarantees that integers can be represented exactly in this type until the number of significant digits is exceeded. Of the 64 bits in a Java "double", 53 bits are used in the mantissa giving 15.95 significant decimal digits. For simplicity, this is rounded down to 15. As the money values are expected to use two significant digits to the right of the decimal point, the magnitude limit imposed is 1.0e13. The maximum magnitude is an exclusive limit; the magnitude of money values must be less than this magnitude and may not be equal to it.

See Also:

getDomainClass

public java.lang.Class<?> getDomainClass()

Gets the class that is used for the native Java representation of data in this domain. The converter's format should be able to format instances of this class and the parse method should return instances of this class.

The client infrastructure will use this class to ensure that the converter methods are not passed an object of an incompatible type by checking this class in the implementation of the acceptData(Object) method inherited from the AbstractConverter base class.

Returns:
The curam.util.type.Money class.
